Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2015 03:34PM crmnsuga1973 wrote: RockMommaof2, I feel like you do sometimes. Ok I lot of times. I got myself into therapy because my phobia of cancer is pretty ugly. I will tell you one thing the doc told me, until you are diagnosed, you are not sick, so live. Sure something is amiss, but until a definite answer is given we have to get up and live. And if we get bad news, we still have to get up and live to fight. I have to remind myself sometimes because being in limbo and waiting is the worst for anxiety. Hoping for good results for us all.

Posts.Title: IBC Worry juneinpa Lala-44

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2015 06:20PM crmnsuga1973 wrote: hi, I found a palpable lump and showed my doctor, got immediate referral for 3d mammo and u/s. Seems standard practice here in my neck of the woods. 2d and 3d screening are done at the same time, so if you've had a mammo before it will be the same. Because my lump didnt show n either I was sent to MRI. MRI was a little uncomfortable. You lay face own, drop your breasts in these little areas here they clamp them in place. No more pressure than a mammo. There is a bar, if you will, that you lay on that separates your breast, not comfy for breathing, but bearable. Arms overhead and a squeeze ball to stop at any time. It took 30 to 45 minutes. I'm claustrophobic and managed to fall sleep during mine. Dress lightly, it gets warm. Hope that helps.
Posts.Title: MY symptoms and concerns while I wait JesusLVS JesusLVS

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2015 11:21PM crmnsuga1973 wrote: MrsDruhl, Be tenacious in follow up. If your body doesn't feel right, push them to act on it. Have you done mammogram and ultrasound? If it doesn't show up on either, ask for mri and/or biopsy...and get new doc. We pay to see them, they work for us, dont let them make you feel wrong. You have a lump and it needs to be taken seriously, period.

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2015 01:44PM crmnsuga1973 wrote: Breast changes happen monthly, so it is usually good idea to do your exam a week after your period. I schedule mine in my calendar for the same day each month. Have your doctor step you thru a self exam, explaining what you can feel and what type tissue it is. This way you get to know your breasts and can tell when your "normal" changes.
